1.comment: Pronounced Ah-bare-toh. Etymology: Portuguese for 'open'. Compare Spanish 'abierto'.
1.content: Charm: A spell used to open doors.

2.comment: Used by Albus Dumbledore to stop underage students from entering their names into the Goblet of Fire. When Fred and George Weasley attempted to circumvent it with Ageing Potions, and ended up in the Hospital Wing with fine white beards, along with other students who tried similar tactics.
2.content: Charm: Prevents people above or below a certain age from access to a target.

3.content: Spell: This spell was, supposedly, quite powerful as when it was cast, the opponent was forced to conjure a silver shield to deflect it.

4.comment: It was used by Dumbledore in the Ministry of Magic, immediately following the Battle of the Department of Mysteries on 17 June, 1996, while he duelled Voldemort.
4.content: Spell: This spell was, supposedly, quite powerful as when it was cast, the opponent was forced to conjure a silver shield to deflect it.

5.comment: Pronounced ah-LOH-ho-MOR-ah. Etymology: The incantation is derived from the West African Sidiki dialect used in geomancy; it means "friendly to thieves". Used by Hermione Granger in 1991 to allow her and her friends to access the Third-floor corridor at her school, which was at the time forbidden; she used it again two years later to free Sirius's cell in her teacher's prison room.
5.content: Charm: Unlocks doors and other locked objects. It can also unlock doors that have been sealed with a Locking Spell, although it is possible to bewitch doors to become unaffected by this spell.

6.comment: Pronounced ah-MAH-toh ah-NEE-moh ah-nee-MAH-toh an-a-MAY-jus. Etymology: Amato is a conjugation of the Latin word amo, which means "I love" or "I am obliged to". Animo and animato are both different conjugations of the Latin word animo, which can mean "I animate" or "I fill with breath or life". Animagus on the other hand appears to be a portmanteau of animo or "animal", and magus, which is Latin for "wizard". Overall, the incantation can roughly mean "My love brings me life, I am obliged to become an animal wizard."
6.content: Transfiguration: Part of the process of becoming an Animagus. The incantation has to be recited at sunrise and sundown, every day before the consumption of the Animagus Potion. The incantation is also recited just prior to consuming the potion, just after a lightning storm starts. The incantation is recited while placing the wand's tip over one's heart.

7.comment: Pronounced an-tee-oh-kyoo-LAY-chee-ah. This spell was used to make Pansy Parkinson grow antlers in 1996.
7.content: Dark charm: Causes the target to grow antlers.

8.comment: Pronounced an-tee-oh-kyoo-LAY-chee-ah. This spell was used to make Pansy Parkinson grow antlers in 1996.
8.content: Dark charm: Causes the target to grow antlers.

9.comment: Pronounced ah-PAR-ay ves-TEE-jee-um. Newton Scamander used it to search for Porpentina Goldstein.
9.content: Charm: Reveals traces of magic, including footprints and track marks.

10.comment: Pronounced ah-PAR-ay ves-TEE-jee-um. Newton Scamander used it to search for Porpentina Goldstein.
10.content: Charm: Reveals traces of magic, including footprints and track marks.

11.comment: Pronounced ah-REST-oh mo-MEN-tum. Etymology: Likely the combination of the Anglo-French arester, meaning "to bring to a stop" and the Latin momentum, meaning "the force or strength gained whilst moving"; the literal translation hence is "Bring the force or strength gained whilst moving to a stop". Used by Dumbledore to save one of his students from a fall in 1993; Hermione Granger used it, to little effect, in 1998 to cushion an otherwise deadly fall.
11.content: Charm: Decreases the velocity of a moving target. Can be used on multiple targets, as well as on the caster themselves. It was invented by Daisy Pennifold in 1711 for use on the Quaffle in Quidditch.

12.comment: Pronounced ah-REST-oh mo-MEN-tum. Etymology: Likely the combination of the Anglo-French arester, meaning "to bring to a stop" and the Latin momentum, meaning "the force or strength gained whilst moving"; the literal translation hence is "Bring the force or strength gained whilst moving to a stop". Used by Dumbledore to save one of his students from a fall in 1993; Hermione Granger used it, to little effect, in 1998 to cushion an otherwise deadly fall.
12.content: Charm: Decreases the velocity of a moving target. Can be used on multiple targets, as well as on the caster themselves. It was invented by Daisy Pennifold in 1711 for use on the Quaffle in Quidditch.

13.comment: Pronounced ah-REST-oh mo-MEN-tum. Etymology: Likely the combination of the Anglo-French arester, meaning "to bring to a stop" and the Latin momentum, meaning "the force or strength gained whilst moving"; the literal translation hence is "Bring the force or strength gained whilst moving to a stop". Used by Dumbledore to save one of his students from a fall in 1993; Hermione Granger used it, to little effect, in 1998 to cushion an otherwise deadly fall.
13.content: Charm: Decreases the velocity of a moving target. Can be used on multiple targets, as well as on the caster themselves. It was invented by Daisy Pennifold in 1711 for use on the Quaffle in Quidditch.

14.comment: Pronounced AH-vi-fors. Etymology: From Latin avis meaning "bird" and forma meaning "shape". Taught in Transfiguration class.
14.content: Transfiguration: Transforms the target into a bird.

15.comment: Pronounced AH-vi-fors. Etymology: From Latin avis meaning "bird" and forma meaning "shape". Taught in Transfiguration class.
15.content: Transfiguration: Transforms the target into a bird.

16.comment: Pronounced AH-vi-fors. Etymology: From Latin avis meaning "bird" and forma meaning "shape". Taught in Transfiguration class.
16.content: Transfiguration: Transforms the target into a bird.

17.comment: Pronounced ah-ven-SEH-gwim. Etymology: The incantation Avenseguim is likely derived from the portmanteau of avens, a Latin adjective for "eager" or "craving", and seguir, the Spanish and Portuguese verb meaning "to follow", or alternatively from the Catalan seguim, meaning "we follow". Taken together, Avenseguim can be interpreted as "to eagerly follow", which aptly characterises the behaviour of a tracking device. In 1927, Newton Scamander used this spell to track the origins of a feather - a clue found during his search for Porpentina Goldstein - back to Yusuf Kama, whose hat the feather came from.
17.content: Charm: Turns an object into a tracking device.

18.comment: Pronounced AH-viss. Etymology: The Latin word avis means "bird". Used in 1994 by Mr Ollivander to test Viktor Krum's wand. Also employed offensively by Hermione Granger against Ron Weasley.
18.content: Conjuration, Charm: Conjures a flock of birds from the tip of the wand. When used in conjunction with Oppugno, it can be used offensively.

19.comment: Pronounced baw-BILL-ee-us. Etymology: Currently unclear, probably from English bauble. This is likely the incantation for White sparks.
19.content: Charm[15]: The exact effects of the spell are unknown, though it presumably is of damaging nature and it produces a bolt of white light from the tip of the wand.

20.comment: Pronounced bom-BAR-dah. Etymology: From the word bombard, meaning "to attack a place or person continually with bombs or other missiles". Taught in fourth year Charms class.

21.content: Charm: Creates a large explosion capable of removing entire walls. A more advanced and more powerful form of the Exploding Charm.

22.comment: Pronounced BRA-key-um ee-MEN-doh. Etymology: The word Brackium is likely derived from the Latin word "Bracchium" meaning "Forearm" or just "Arm", and Emendo, from the Latin word of the same spelling, meaning "I Correct" or "I Improve", the full meaning would be "I Correct/Improve the Forearm". Used unsuccessfully by Gilderoy Lockhart on Harry Potter in 1992 after the latter's arm was broken by a Bludger; it vanished all the bones, making it resemble rubber.
22.content: Charm, Healing Spell: If used correctly, it is claimed that this spell will heal broken bones; this theory is supported by the etymology.

23.comment: Pronounced cal-VOR-ee-oh. Etymology: From Latin calvus = "bald". The book Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian mentions this curse.

24.comment: Pronounced CAN-tiss. Etymology: Cantare is Latin for "sing". Used by the Hogwarts professors to enchant suits of armour.
24.content: Charm: Causes the victim to burst uncontrollably into song.

25.comment: Pronounced ca-PAY-shus ex-TREEM-us. Etymology: 'Capacious in English means when the capacity is very extreme, and Extremis is in latin, extreme. Meaning "Extreme Capacity" Newton Scamander used this spell to expand his suitcase so he could fit through and access the inside. Arthur Weasley used this spell to allow eight people, six large trunks, two owls, and a rat to fit comfortably inside his modified Ford Anglia in 1992. Also on the tent in which the Weasleys, Harry and Hermione stay during the Quidditch World Cup in 1994; the tent is also used by Harry, Ron and Hermione as shelter in 1997. Also, Hermione cast this spell upon her handbag in the same year.
25.content: Charm: Expands the internal dimensions of an object without affecting the external dimensions, enhancing its capacity, and rendering its contents lighter.

26.comment: Pronounced CAR-pay ruh-TRACK-tum. Etymology: From the Latin carpe, meaning "to seize" and retracto, meaning "I draw back". Taught in third year Charms class.
26.content: Charm: Produces a rope of light used to pull objects towards the caster, or, if the target is fixed in place, to pull the caster towards the target.

27.comment: Pronounced CAH-vay uh-NIM-i-kuhm. Etymology: The incantation is a Latin phrase which translates to "beware of the enemy". Used multiple times by Hermione Granger in 1997 and 1998 to protect the tent she shared with Ron Weasley and Harry Potter.
27.content: Charm: Produces a boundary that keeps the caster hidden from others.

28.content: Charm: Causes plants within a greenhouse to grow at an accelerated rate. It was created by combining elements of the Herbivicus Charm and Gemino Curse.

29.comment: Pronounced SIR-cum-roh-tuh. This spell was used by Leta Lestrange to rotate a record tower in the Records Room at the French Ministry of Magic Headquarters, revealing Newton Scamander and Porpentina Goldstein to be hiding behind the tower.

30.comment: Pronounced SIS-tem uh-PE-ree-o. Etymology: Aperio is Latin for "uncover" or "open"; Cista is Latin for "trunk" or "chest". This spell was taught in fourth year Charms class at Hogwarts.

31.comment: Pronounced cul-loh-POR-tus. Etymology: Perhaps a portmanteau of the Latin words colligare, which means "restrain" and porta, which means "gate". This spell can easily be countered with Alohomora. Used by Hermione Granger in 1996 in an attempt to prevent the Death Eaters that were following her from catching up.
31.content: Charm: Locks doors and all things that can be locked. It is the counter-charm to the Unlocking Spell.

32.comment: Pronounced CAWL-low-shoo. Etymology: The suffix "shoo" is a phonetic spelling of English "shoe"; the prefix collo may come from Greek "," (pronounced "colao","colo"), which means "to glue". This spell is mentioned twice, once as having been used on Severus Snape during a potions class, the other when one reads Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian.
32.content: Hex: Sticks the target's shoes to the ground.

33.comment: Pronounced co-loh-VA-riah. Etymology: Almost certainly a combination of English "colour" and "vary". Used by fifth-years in their OWLs.

34.comment: Pronounced kon-FRING-goh. Etymology: The incantation is direct Latin for "destroy". This spell seems to use heat for its explosion, while Expulso uses pressure instead. Used by Harry Potter to destroy the side-car of a motorbike in which he was riding during a battle against some Death Eaters in 1997; it was later used by Hermione Granger in an attempt to kill Nagini and facilitate an escape from Godric's Hollow.

35.comment: Pronounced con-FUN-doh. Etymology: The incantation, when non-capitalised, means "I confuse"; the title may derive from the Latin confundere, meaning "to confuse" or "to perplex." In 1994, Severus Snape asserted that Harry, Ron and Hermione had this charm cast on them so that they would believe Sirius Black's claim of innocence; used two years later by Hermione to allow Ron to join the Gryffindor Quidditch team. It was used multiple times in 1997 and 1998.
35.content: Charm: Causes the victim to become confused and befuddled.

36.comment: This maybe be the spell that caused Harry to turn his eyebrow yellow in 1996. Harry may have used this spell to turn his teacher's hair blue.
36.content: Transfiguration: Used to transfigure the colour and style of one's hair.

37.comment: Pronounced KROO-see-oh. Etymology: Latin crucio means "I torture". Infamously used by Death Eaters Bellatrix Lestrange, Rabastan Lestrange, Rodolphus Lestrange and Bartemius Crouch Junior to torture the Aurors Frank and Alice Longbottom into insanity.
37.content: Curse: Inflicts intense pain on the recipient of the curse. This curse does not physically harm the victim, but may in extreme cases drive them insane. The pain is described as having hot knives being driven into the victim. It cannot be cast successfully by a person who is doing so out of pure spite or anger; one must feel a true desire to cause the victim pain. If one casts this spell, he or she will receive a life sentence in Azkaban prison for it, as with the other two Unforgivable Curses.

38.comment: Pronounced deh-FOH-dee-oh. Etymology: The incantation is Latin for "I dig". Used by The Trio to escape from a bank in 1998 while riding a dragon. It was later used by Harry to write the epitaph for Dobby, who had been killed.
38.content: Charm: Allows the caster to dig and carve through the target.

39.comment: Pronounced deh-LEE-tree-us. Etymology: Latin delere, meaning "to destroy", and English "detritus", meaning rubble. This spell was only ever seen in 1994 when Amos Diggory used Prior Incantato to detect that Winky had cast Morsmordre using Harry Potter's wand.
39.content: Charm: Counter-charm to the Reverse Spell, vanishing the image of the last spell cast. It may also disintegrate other certain images.

40.comment: Pronounced den-SAW-jee-oh. Etymology: From Latin dens, meaning "tooth", and augeo, meaning "I enlarge"; essentially, it means "I enlarge the tooth". Introduced in 1994, when Draco Malfoy's spell rebounded upon Hermione Granger; her teeth were past her collar before she was forced to run to the hospital to get them shrunk.
40.content: Hex: This hex causes the victim's teeth to grow rapidly.

41.comment: Pronounced deh-PREEM-oh. Etymology: The incantation, when non-capitalised, means "to depress" or "depress". Hermione Granger blasted a hole through the living room floor of Xenophilius Lovegood's house in 1998 using this spell.
41.content: Charm: Charm used to blast holes in the ground.

42.comment: Pronounced deh-PUL-soh. Etymology: From the Latin depulsio, meaning "drive away". Although it is learned in the fourth-year charms class at Hogwarts, it is used multiple times in 1993, as well as in 1995.
42.content: Charm: Sends the target away from the caster. It is the counter-charm to the Summoning Charm.

43.comment: Pronounced deh-SEN-doh. Etymology: Descendo is Latin for "I descend". In 1997, it was used by Ron to magically cause the stairs in his bedroom, which lead to his family's attic, to descend; later that year, Crabbe used it in an attempt to cause a wall of rubbish behind which Ron was hiding to fall on him.
43.content: Charm: Causes object to fall or move downwards.

44.comment: Pronounced dih-FIN-doh. Etymology: Latin diffindere, meaning "to divide" or "to split". Used twice in 1994, the first time being by Harry Potter to cut Cedric Diggory's bag in order to talk to the latter, and the second time being by Ron Weasley to cut the lace from the cuffs of his dress robes in an attempt to make them seem less feminine. The spell was used a third time by Harry to swap the covers of his second-hand and brand-new copies of Advanced Potion-Making.
44.content: Charm: Used to precisely cut or tear objects.

45.comment: Pronounced dim-in-YEW-en-DOUGH. Etymology: The incantation derives from the musical term diminuendo, meaning "a gradual decrease of the volume of sound". Performed by Nigel Wolpert in 1995, during a Dumbledore's Army meeting.
45.content: Charm: Forces the target to shrink.

46.comment: Pronounced dih-SEN-dee-um. Etymology: There are numerous suggestions. This may not be a spell at all in the strict sense but a password; however, when used for the statue of the hump-backed witch, one must tap the statue with their wand, indicating that it is in fact a spell. Used multiple times in 1993 to open the statue of Gunhilda of Gorsemoor, then again four years later in a failed attempt to open Salazar Slytherin's Locket.

47.comment: Pronounced drah-KOH-nih-fors. Etymology: From the Latin word draco, meaning "dragon", and forma meaning "shape". Taught in third year Transfiguration class.
47.content: Transfiguration: Transforms the target into a dragon.

48.comment: Pronounced DUCK-lih-fors. Etymology: From the English duck, and the Latin forma meaning "shape".
48.content: Transfiguration, Jinx: Transforms the target into a duck.

49.comment: Pronounced DYOO-roh. Etymology: Latin duro means "harden". Used by Hermione Granger in 1998 while escaping from Death Eaters in the Battle of Hogwarts.
49.content: Charm: Turns an object to stone.

50.comment: Pronounced ee-BUB-lee-oh. Used often by members of the Statute of Secrecy Task Force.
50.content: Jinx: Causes the victim to be trapped in a large bubble.

51.comment: Pronounced en-GOR-jee-oh. Etymology: The English word engorge means "swell". There is much speculation that this spell is the same as the Growth Charm, though this cannot be proven. Note that there is a difference between enlarging and engorging something, similar though they may seem. Rubeus Hagrid used this spell on his pumpkins in 1992; two years later, Barty Crouch Jnr cast this spell on a spider to make it easier for students to see when he cast a curse on it. Used on another spider three years later to test a new wand.
51.content: Charm: Causes the target to swell in physical size. Its counter-charm is the Shrinking Charm.

52.comment: Pronounced in-GORE-jee-oh SKUH-las. Etymology: See etymology for above entry; "skullus" is Latin for "skull".
52.content: Dark charm: Causes the victim's skull to swell disproportionately. This spell may be a variation of the Engorgement Charm, as they share the first word of the incantation. Its countercurse is Redactum Skullus.

53.comment: Pronounced en-TOE-morph-is. Harry Potter contemplated using this jinx against Dudley Dursley in 1995, though he decided against it.
53.content: Jinx, Transfiguration: This jinx is used to transform the target into an insectoid for a short time.

54.comment: Pronounced ee-PIS-key. Etymology: The word comes from Greek "episkeui" (""), which means "repair". This is part of a family of healing spells. In 1996, Nymphadora Tonks used this spell to fix Harry's broken nose after Draco Malfoy broke it on the Hogwarts Express, Harry, in turn, used it to heal Demelza Robins' swollen lip after Ron punched her during Quidditch practice.
54.content: Healing Spell: Used to heal relatively minor injuries, such as broken bones and cartilage.

55.comment: Pronounced ee-POX-i-mise. Etymology: Epoximise comes from the English word epoxy, which is a type of adhesive. This spell may be the Permanent Sticking Charm or a variation. This spell is often used by students to adhere each other's belongings to their desks (or, unfortunately, their hands).
55.content: Transfiguration: Adheres one object to another, as if they had been glued together.

56.comment: Pronounced eh-RECK-toh. Etymology: Erectum is past principle of erigere, which is Latin for "to erect". Used by Hermione Granger to construct a shelter for her, Harry Potter, and Ronald Weasley in 1997.
56.content: Charm: Used to erect a tent or other upright structure.

57.comment: Pronounced ev-an-ES-key. This and the Vanishing Spell are almost certainly the same spell.

58.comment: Pronounced ev-an-ES-koh. Etymology: From "evanescene", meaning "something that is fleeting or disappears. Used by William Weasley to vanish a bundle of old scrolls whilst cleaning 12 Grimmauld Place in 1995.
58.content: Transfiguration: Vanishes the target. Vanished things go "into non-being, which is to say, everything."

59.comment: Pronounced ee-VER-tay STAH-tum. Etymology: The Latin words everte, which means "to throw out" and statua, from the same language, meaning "image". Draco Malfoy used this spell on Harry Potter in 1992 during the Duelling Club.
59.content: Spell: Throws the victim backward, similarly to being thrown.

60.comment: Pronounced ecks-PECK-toh pah-TROH-numb. Etymology: Patronus means "protector" in Latin; in archaic Latin, it means "father"; considering the form Harry's takes, this is interesting. The Latin word expecto means "I await" Taught to Harry Potter by Remus Lupin during his Anti-Dementor lessons; Harry later taught Dumbledore's Army this charm. This is the only known spell effective against Dementors or Lethifolds.
60.content: Charm: This charm is a highly powerful and advanced protective spell which will conjure a spirit guardian of their positive emotions to defend against dark creatures; it can also send messages to other witches or wizards. The Patronus takes the form of an animal, unique to each person who casts it. The form of a Patronus can change when one has undergone a period of heightened emotion.

61.comment: Pronounced ex-PELL-ee-ARE-muss. Etymology: Probably a combination of Latin expello, meaning "expel", and arma, meaning "weapon". Used by Severus Snape on Gilderoy Lockhart during a live duelling demonstration during the first and last meeting of the Duelling Club in 1992.
61.content: Charm: Forces whatever an opponent is holding to fly out of their hand. It was considered to be Harry Potter's signature spell.

62.comment: Pronounced ecks-PUHL-soh. Etymology: From expulsum, which is past principle of expellere, which means "expel". Used by Antonin Dolohov during a fight in a cafe in 1997.
62.content: Curse: Provokes an explosion, unique in that it uses pressure to do so as opposed to heat.

63.comment: Pronounced fer-ROOL-lah. Etymology: Latin ferula means "walking-stick" or "splint". Used by Remus Lupin in 1994 to bind Ronald Weasley's broken leg.
63.content: Conjuration, Healing spell: Conjures up bandages and wraps them around a wound, splinting any broken bones.

64.comment: Pronounced fee-AN-toh DOO-ree. Etymology: Latin fiant means "become" and duri means "hard". Used to protect Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry in 1998.
64.content: Charm: A defensive charm which, based on the etymology, strengthens shield spells, and perhaps objects in general, in a similar way to Duro.

65.comment: Pronounced fi-NESS-tra. On 6 December 1926, Newt Scamander shattered the front window of the Voclain & Co. jewellery store in New York using this spell to try and recapture his escaped niffler when he saw it loose inside the store stealing things.

66.comment: Pronounced fi-NEE-tay in-can-TAH-tem. Etymology: Latin finire, meaning "to finish", and incantatem. Severus Snape used this to restore order to the Duelling Club in 1992, after the event had descended into utter chaos.
66.content: Counter-Spell: Terminates all spell effects in the vicinity of the caster.

67.comment: Pronounced flah-GRAH-tay. Etymology: From the Latin flagrate, meaning "a burn". Tom Riddle used this spell to write his name; Hermione Granger used it three years later to mark some doors.
67.content: Charm: Writes in midair with firey marks.

68.comment: Pronounced FLINT-i-fors. This may be related to, or the incantation for Match to needle. In the 1980s, this spell was covered in third year transfiguration classes.

69.comment: Pronounced fli-PEN-doh. Taught in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts and Charms class.
69.content: Jinx: Knocks objects and creatures backwards.

70.content: Jinx: A more powerful version of Flipendo.

71.comment: Invented by Badeea Ali in the 19891990 school year, who taught it to fellow sixth year students.
71.content: Jinx: A more powerful version of the Knockback Jinx, which threw the target back at a much greater force.

72.content: Jinx: A more powerful version of Flipendo Duo; it is said to resemble a miniature tornado.

73.comment: Pronounced Fracto Strata (Pronunciation Unknown). Etymology: From the Latin fractus, meaning broken, and stratus, meaning spread out or covered. This is the main offensive spell used in the LEGO Harry Potter
73.content: Spell: zap-type spell which can break weak objects into pieces.

74.comment: Pronounced FYOO-moss. This spell is covered in The Dark Forces
74.content: Charm: Defensive smokescreen that hinders visibility.

75.content: Charm: A more powerful version of Fumos.

76.comment: Pronounced fer-NUN-kyoo-luss. Etymology: Latin furnunculus, meaning "petty thief", or English furuncle, a synonym for "boil". Used by Harry Potter on Gregory Goyle.
76.content: Jinx: Covers the target in boils (or pimples).

77.comment: Pronounced jeh-MIH-nee-oh. Etymology: The Latin word gemini means "twins". Used by Hermione Granger on Salazar Slytherin's Locket to disguise her presence from Dolores Umbridge. Also used in the Lestrange family vault to keep the trio from stealing the horcrux.
77.content: Charm: Duplicates the target. When used to duplicate objects indefinitely on purpose, is known as the Gemino Curse.

78.comment: Pronounced GLAY-see-us. Etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice". Not to be confused with the Freezing Charm, which merely immobilises things.
78.content: Charm: Freezes the target with icy-cold air.

79.comment: Pronounced GLAY-see-us DOO-oh. Etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice".
79.content: Charm: A more powerful version of Glacius.

80.comment: Pronounced GLAY-see-us TREE-ah. Etymology: From Latin glacies, which means "ice".
80.content: Charm: A more powerful version of Glacius Duo.

81.comment: Pronounced GLISS-ee-oh. Etymology: Probably derived from French glisser, meaning "to slide". Used by Hermione Granger to escape from Death Eaters.
81.content: Charm: Causes the steps on a stairway to flatten into a slide.

82.comment: Pronounced har-MOH-nee-a NECK-teh-ray PASS-us. Etymology: Latin harmonia, which means "harmony", nectere, which means "to bind", and passus, which means "step". Used by Draco Malfoy to mend a cabinet in 1996.

83.content: Transfiguration: This spell causes flowers to sprout from the victim.

84.comment: Pronounced her-BIV-i-cuss. Taught by Professor Pomona Sprout in Herbology classes.

85.comment: Pronounced HOM-eh-num reh-VEH-lee-oh. Etymology: Most likely from Latin homo, meaning human, and "reveal", though the classical Latin form would be hominem instead of homenum, which shows Portuguese influence ("man" is homem in Portuguese). It can be used non-verbally; Dumbledore does so to detect Harry underneath his Invisibility Cloak. Used multiple times by various people in 1997.
85.content: Charm: Reveals human presence in the vicinity of the caster.

86.content: Charm: Makes writing impossible to read.

87.comment: Pronounced ih-MOH-byoo-luhs. Etymology: From the Latin immobilis, meaning immovable. Hermione used it 1992 to freeze two Cornish Pixies. Horace Slughorn used Freezing Charms to disable a Muggle Burglar Alarm.
87.content: Charm: Immobilises and stops the actions of the target. It works both on living and inanimate things.

88.comment: Pronounced im-ped-ih-MEN-tah. Etymology: Latin impedimentum (plural impedimenta), "a hindrance" or "an impediment". Used in 1995 when Harry was practising for the Third Task of the Triwizard Tournament. In 1996, Harry saw in a memory that James Potter used it on Severus Snape. Also used in 1997 by Harry against the Inferi and Snape. Stronger uses of this spell seem capable of blowing targets away.
88.content: Jinx: Slows down or stops the target.

89.comment: Pronounced im-PEER-ee-oh. Etymology: Latin impero, I command, and English "imperious". Used on many occasions. First seen in 1994 when Barty Crouch Jnr, impersonating ex-Auror Alastor Moody, used it on a spider and later on students during a "class demonstration" in a Defence Against the Dark Arts class. While breaking into Gringotts in 1998, Harry used it on a goblin and a Death Eater when they became suspicious.
89.content: Curse: Places the victim completely under the caster's control. The victim is put into a trance-like state, and becomes very suggestible to the commands of the caster. However, those who are strong willed may learn to resist it. One of the three "Unforgivable Curses," the use of this curse on another human results in capital punishment or life sentence in Azkaban.

90.comment: Pronounced im-PUR-vee-us. Etymology: It is said that the Latin impervius means (and is the source of) "impervious"; although it is the source of the word, it is better translated as impassable, as in a mountain peak. Used by Hermione Granger in 1993 on Harry's glasses while in a Quidditch match and also by the Gryffindor Quidditch team. Also used in 1997, first by Ron to protect objects in Yaxley's office from rain, and then by Hermione to protect Harry, Ron and Griphook from the burning treasure in the Lestranges' vault.
90.content: Charm: Makes an object repel water and mist.

91.comment: Pronounced in-an-ih-MAH-tus CON-jur-us. Mentioned briefly in 1995.
91.content: Transfiguration: It is a spell of unknown effect, most likely used to conjure an inanimate object.

92.comment: Pronounced in-KAR-ser-us. Etymology: Probably English incarcerate, "to imprison". Possibly linked to the Latin in carcerem, "in(to) prison". A non-verbal version of this spell may have been used to tie up Remus Lupin by Severus Snape during the encounter in the Shrieking Shack, and then later Peter Pettigrew in 1994. It may also have been used by Quirrell in 1992, although he is said to have merely "snapped his fingers". Also, it may have been the spell Antonin Dolohov used non-verbally to bind Ron Weasley with "shining black ropes" in a skirmish on Tottenham Court Road. Used 1996, when Dolores Umbridge tries to hold off Centaurs. Also used by Harry on the Inferi in Voldemort's Crystal Cave in 1997 and also attempted to use it on Severus Snape in the same year.
92.content: Conjuration: Ties up the target with ropes conjured from thin air.

93.comment: Pronounced in-SEN-dee-oh. Etymology: Latin incendere, "to set fire (to)". Note that the first principal part of this verb (meaning "I set fire") is incendo, not incendio; the incantation does not match exactly any correct conjugation of the verb. Incndio, in Portuguese (same pronunciation as in English) means 'huge fire'. "Encender" in Spanish means "to ignite" and "Incendie" in French means flame. (A plausible but less likely source might be that it is a back-formation from the English word "incendiary," i.e., "causing fire.") It was used in 1994 by Arthur Weasley to create a fire in the Dursleys' hearth so that he could use Floo Powder there.

94.content: Charm: A stronger version of Incendio.

95.content: Charm: An improvement over both Incendio and Incendio Duo.

96.comment: Pronounced in-FLAY-tus. Etymology: The prefix 'Inflate' derives from the English verb "to expand with oxygen".
96.content: Jinx: Inflates the target, filling it with air.

97.comment: Pronounced in-FOR-m-es. Etymology: The prefix Info derives from the English verb "to inform".
97.content: Charm: Informous is a spell that is used to complete one's Folio Bruti. A page with a brief description (including weaknesses and strengths) of the charmed creature is added to the caster's Folio Bruti.

98.comment: Pronounced loh-koh-MOH-tor WIB-lee. One of the spells mentioned in Curses and Counter-Curses by Vindictus Viridian, used on Harry, practising for the Third Task of the Triwizard Tournament, by Hermione. Also, Draco Malfoy was hit with this jinx (along with another one) at the end of the term.
98.content: Curse, Jinx: Causes the victim's legs to collapse as if they were turned to jelly.

99.comment: Pronounced la-KAR-num in-flah-MAR-ee. Etymology: Latin inflammo, or the verb inflammatio meaning "to set on fire". Lacarnum, from the Latin lacerna, meaning cloak.

100.comment: Pronounced LANG-lock. Etymology: Probably from the French langue ("tongue") and the English "lock". Used by Harry on Peeves and twice on Argus Filch, to general applause.
100.content: Jinx: Sticks a victim's tongue to the roof of their mouth. Created by Severus Snape.

101.comment: Pronounced LAP-ih-forz. Etymology: From Latin lepus meaning hare, and forma meaning "shape". Taught in third year Transfiguration class.
101.content: Transfiguration: Transforms the target into a rabbit.

102.comment: Pronounced Le-JIL-ih-mens. Etymology: Latin legere ("to read") and mens ("mind"). Used by Severus Snape on Harry after he had a dream about Arthur Weasley being attacked by Nagini in 1995. Also during Occlumency lessons in 1996. Also used non-verbally by Snape on Harry in 1997 to allow him to see where Harry had learned the Sectumsempra spell.
102.content: Charm: Allows the caster to delve into the mind of the victim, allowing the caster to see the memories, thoughts, and emotions of the victim.

103.comment: Pronounced leh-vee-COR-pus. Etymology: Latin levare, "raise" and corpus, "body" or "corpse". Apparently invented by the Half-Blood Prince; it is a non-verbal-only spell (although it is whispered by Hermione in 1997). Harry Potter learnt it by reading the notes written by the Half-Blood Prince. He used it on Ron. The previous year, Harry had seen (through the Pensieve used by Severus Snape) his father, James Potter, use the spell against Professor Snape.
103.content: Jinx: Hoists people up into the air by their ankle. Created by Severus Snape.

104.comment: Pronounced LIB-er-ah-cor-pus. Etymology: Latin liberare, "to free", and corpus, "body" or "corpse". It is not clear why Levicorpus has a specific counter-spell, and is not neutralised by simply using Finite Incantatem, although this could be due to the fact that Snape invented the spell and therefore made it irreversible except by its specific counter-curse. Harry used the spell in 1996 to counteract Levicorpus he had inadvertently cast on Ron.

105.comment: Pronounced loh-kuh-MOH-tor. Etymology: Latin locus (place) and moto, "set in motion" (passive motor), or English locomotion. Used by Nymphadora Tonks in Harry Potter to move Harry's trunk from his room. Filius Flitwick similarly used it to move Sybill Trelawney's trunk after Dolores Umbridge sacked her. Parvati Patil and Lavender Brown used this spell to race their pencil cases around the edges of the table. A variation seen in 1998 is Piertotum Locomotor, which caused the statues of Hogwarts to be animated.
105.content: Charm: Allows a witch or wizard to levitate a target a few inches off of the ground and then move said object in any given direction. Similarly to the Summoning Charm, a specific object can be moved by calling the object aloud after saying the incantation.

106.comment: Pronounced LOH-koh-moh-tor MOR-tis. Etymology: English locomotion, "movement" + Latin mortis, "of death". It is unclear whether or how this spell is related to the Locomotor spell. It could, however, be that the curse "locks" any part of the body in accordance to where it is pointed, or moves the body into a position of the caster's choosing whilst placing them into an immobile state. It is possible that Draco had pointed his wand at Neville and the curse "locked" his legs together. Used by Draco Malfoy on Neville Longbottom in 1991. Used by Harry Potter on Draco Malfoy, who deflected it, in 1996.

107.comment: Pronounced LOO-mos. Etymology: Latin lumen, "light". opposite incantation, Nox, puts the light out. Used by Albus Dumbledore to illuminate the dark cave in 1997.
107.content: Charm: Illuminates the tip of the caster's wand, allowing the caster to see in the dark.

108.comment: Pronounced LOO-mos DOO-oh. Etymology: Lumos plus Latin duo, "two".
108.content: Charm: Creates a focused beam of light from the end of the wand. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.

109.comment: Pronounced LOO-mos Ma-cks-ima. Etymology: Lumos + maxima, Latin "greatest." First practised by Harry in the home of the Dursleys, then used by Dumbledore to light up the cave of the Horcrux.
109.content: Charm: Produces a blinding flash of bright white light from the tip of the wand. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.

110.comment: Pronounced LOO-mos SO-lem. Etymology: Derived from two words; the Latin lumen, meaning "light", and the Latin word for "sun", which in its accusative case is "solem". It is possible that the quality of the light is on the warmer solar end of the spectrum; Considering the known uses that the spell has been put to, it isn't that much of a stretch to presume that the spell is used to conjure Sunlight. Used by Hermione to free Ron from the Devil's Snare. The incantation was only used in the film adaptation of Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone.
110.content: Charm: Produce a blinding flash of sunlight. It is a variant of the Wand-Lighting Charm.

111.content: Charm: Partnership-based charm that temporarily increases the casters' spell power.

112.comment: Cornelius Fudge was rumoured to have been a victim of this jinx after having been overpowered by Albus Dumbledore in a duel in 1996.
112.content: Jinx: Encases the victim's head in a pumpkin.

113.comment: Pronounced mee-tee-OH-loh-jinks reh-CAN-toh.. Etymology: Meteorology, the study of weather, the word jinx and recant, "to withdraw or retract". Interestingly in modern English recant means to say that you no longer hold a belief. Suggested in 1997 by Arthur Weasley to Ron (disguised as Reginald Cattermole by use of Polyjuice Potion) as the best way to clear up the rain jinx on a Ministry office. Also used by Bartemius Crouch Jnr (Disguised as Alastor Moody) In 1994 to cease the weather effect of the Great Hall's Ceiling insisting it is broken as he told Dumbledore to "Fix his ceiling".
113.content: Counter-Charm: Causes weather effects caused by jinxes to cease.

114.comment: Pronounced MIM-bull-wim-bull. Seen in 1997 as a deterrent to Severus Snape, or any other unwanted visitor of 12 Grimmauld Place, from betraying their location to anyone else.
114.content: Curse: Ties the target's tongue in a knot, preventing them from making coherent speech, or saying incantations correctly, making it useful in duels.

115.comment: Pronounced mo-bil-lee-AR-bus. Etymology: Latin mobilis, "movable" or "flexible", and arbor (alternatively arbos), "tree". It is possible that Mobilicorpus and Mobiliarbus are variations of the same basic spell, since they share the "Mobili-" stem. In 1993, Hermione Granger used the spell to move a Christmas Tree in The Three Broomsticks beside her table to hide Harry Potter, who was in Hogsmeade illegally.
115.content: Charm: Levitates wooden objects a few inches off of the ground and moves them in any given direction.

116.comment: Pronounced moh-bil-lee-COR-pus. Etymology: Latin mobilis, "movable", and corpus, "body". It is possible that Mobiliarbus and Mobilicorpus are variations of the same basic spell, since they share the "Mobili-" stem. Sirius Black used it on Severus Snape in 1994. It was probably used on Peter Pettigrew by Lord Voldemort in the graveyard to make him come forward.

117.comment: Pronounced mull-ee-AR-ay. This spell may be related to Arresto Momentum and Spongify. Used by Hermione Granger to cushion her, Harry, and Ron's fall in Gringotts Wizard Bank in 1998.
117.content: Charm: Produces an invisible cushion over the target, is used primarily in the manufacturing of broomsticks.

118.comment: This may be Hardening Charm or Freezing Charm, although the latter is shown to be blue in 1992.
118.content: Dark charm: Like the Killing curse, it kills (or freezes) the victim. It turns the body grey/blue (or paler) while it turns to stone and then another twin spell can blast the body into pieces.

119.comment: Pronounced morz-MOR-druh. Etymology: Latin mors, "death", and mordere, meaning "to bite" (or its French derivative mordre); this would appear to be associated with the name of Lord Voldemort's followers, the Death Eaters. The English murder might also contribute. A possible translation might be "take a bite out of death", a fitting phrase for Death Eaters. Used by Bartemius Crouch Junior in 1994. Also seen in 1997 over Hogwarts castle to lure Albus Dumbledore to his death. It was apparently invented by Lord Voldemort.
119.content: Dark charm: Conjures the Dark Mark, which is the sign of the Death Eaters.

120.comment: Pronounced MYOO-kus ahd NAW-zee-um. Mentioned by Professor Quirrell to his first-year class.
120.content: Curse: Gives the victim a nasty cold and an extremely runny nose that can cause the victim to collapse if it is not treated. The cold is accompanied with constant sneezing.

121.comment: Pronounced muf-lee-AH-to. Etymology: English muffle, "to quiet", with a pseudo-Latin or pseudo-Italian ending. It was used in 1996 by Harry Potter and Ron Weasley on various teachers and people such as Madam Pomfrey. It was created by Severus Snape. As pointed out by Hermione, it is probably not Ministry of Magic approved. It was also used in 1997 by Hermione Granger in protection of the camp-site where Harry and she stayed in hiding.
121.content: Charm: Prevents others from hearing nearby conversations by filling peoples' ears with an unidentifiable buzzing.

122.content: Transfiguration: Multicorfors is a charm used to change the colour and style of one's clothing.

123.comment: Pronounced myoo-TAY-toh SKULL-us. Used by Ancient Egyptian wizards, as noted by Ron Weasley in 1993.
123.content: Dark charm: Mutates the victim's head, causing them to grows extra heads.

124.comment: Pronounced NOCKSS. Etymology: Latin nox,  meaning "night". In  1994, Harry Potter and Hermione Granger used this spell to turn off their wand-lights in the Shrieking Shack.  Used in 1998 when Harry was in the passage beneath the Whomping Willow which leads to the Shrieking Shack. Lumos's power can be arranged so that a powerful wizard can make the charm illuminate intensely or to the wizards liking by loudness of incantation. For example "LUMOS!!!" would be powerful and "lumos" would be weaker. Also used by Harry Potter in 1998 to turn off the light so he could hide the Marauder's Map from Severus Snape.
124.content: Charm: Extinguishes wandlight. It the counter-charm for the Wand-Lighting Charm, Lumos.

125.comment: Pronounced NEH-bu-lus. This may be the incantation for the Ministry of Magic Fog. In 1927, Albus Dumbledore used this spell to conjure a fog in London to provide concealment for his meeting with Newton Scamander.
125.content: Charm: Creates fog from the tip of the wand.

126.comment: This spell is a variation of Reparo. Used by Hermione in 1991 and 1992 to fix Harry's glasses.

127.comment: Pronounced oh-BLI-vee-ate. Etymology: Latin oblivisci, "forget". The spell is most often used against Muggles who have seen something of the Wizarding world. Invented by Mnemone Radford, who became the Ministry's first Obliviator. The Ministry of Magic employees assigned to modifying the memories of Muggles are called Obliviators. The charm can be broken by powerful magic, or extreme duress, as Lord Voldemort was able to torture Bertha Jorkins into remembering details that Barty Crouch Snr had forced her to forget using the charm. In this case, it was also shown that if the charm is too powerful, it can cause the target to develop a bad memory. This spell differs from the False memory charm. First seen in 1993 when used by Gilderoy Lockhart on Harry and Ron; the spell backfired due to a faulty wand, costing Lockhart most of his own memory. Also, Hermione Granger used this spell to wipe her parents memories in 1997. Again, it was used in 1997 when Hermione Granger used the spell on 2 Death Eaters who had followed Harry, Ron, and Hermione after their escape from Bill Weasley's and Fleur Delacour's wedding.

128.comment: Pronounced ob-SKYUR-oh. Etymology: English word obscure, meaning "unclear" or "unnoticeable". This spell might only affect characters in paintings; there are no other references to this spell. Used by Hermione Granger in 1997 to obstruct the portrait of Phineas Nigellus's view of their location.

129.comment: Pronounced oh-PUG-noh. Etymology: Latin oppugno, "I attack". Used by Hermione Granger in 1996 to attack Ron Weasley with a summoned flock of canaries during an argument.
129.content: Jinx: Causes targeted objects to attack a victim. It is particularly effective in conjunction with the Bird-Conjuring Charm.

130.comment: Pronounced OR-biss. Etymology: Orbis is Latin for 'circle', which reflects the spell's physical appearance.
130.content: Jinx: Sucks the target into the ground.

131.comment: Pronounced or-KID-ee-us. Etymology: English orchid and Latin suffix -eous, "of or bearing (the root word)". A variation of this spell may have been used when Hermione Granger conjured a Christmas wreath to place on James and Lily Potter's graves in 1997. Used in 1994 by Mr Ollivander to test Fleur Delacour's wand. Probably used non-verbally by Tom Riddle to present flowers to Mrs Smith.
131.content: Conjuration: Conjures a bouquet of flowers.

132.comment: Pronounced os-SCOW-zee. Etymology: Possibly derived as a portmanteau of os, Latin for "mouth", and clausi (a conjugated form of claudo), Latin for "I shut". It may additionally be a pun or wordplay on scusi, the Italian interjection for "excuse me". Used by Leta Lestrange on a girl from Gryffindor when they were both in their third year at Hogwarts. The Gryffindor girl was speaking ill of Lestrange behind her back until Lestrange emerged from hiding nearby, and muted the Gryffindor girl with this spell.
132.content: Dark charm: Seal someone's mouth shut, making it appear it was never there.

133.comment: Used in 1994 by Remus Lupin in his office, and in 1995 by Nymphadora Tonks, once verbally and again non-verbally.

134.comment: This spell is a variation of Reparo. This spell was used by Newton Scamander in 1927 to restore a torn postcard from Porpentina Goldstein addressed to Queenie Goldstein.
134.content: Charm: Mends torn pieces of paper.

135.comment: Pronounced PAR-tis temp-OAR-us. Etymology: Partis is a plural form of the French verb partir, which means "to separate," "to go away," "to leave," or "to depart." Temporis is Latin for "time." Used by Albus Dumbledore in the Crystal Cave in 1997. He uses it so that he and Harry can pass through the ring of fire used to ward off the Inferi.
135.content: Charm: Creates a temporary gap in the target.

136.comment: Pronounced pur-ICK-you-lum. Etymology: Periculum is Latin for "danger".
136.content: Charm: Produces a burst of red sparks.

137.comment: Pronounced PES-key PIX-ee PES-ter NO-mee. Etymology: English pesky meaning "annoying", English pixie meaning "a supernatural being", English pester meaning "to annoy", English no for negative and English me for the first person pronoun. It is not known if the spell works or not. It also suspiciously sounds like "Pesky pixie pester no me." Used by Lockhart to attempt to remove Cornish Pixies.
137.content: Charm: The one time it was used, it had absolutely no effect.

138.comment: Pronounced pe-TRI-fi-cus to-TAH-lus. Etymology: Latin petra, meaning "stone", and fieri (past participle factus), meaning "to become"; totalus comes from Latin "totus", meaning "complete". Used in 1991 by Hermione, who was trying to prevent Neville from stopping her, Ron, and Harry from leaving the common room to hunt for the Philosopher's Stone,  in the Hall of Prophecy during the Battle of the Department of Mysteries to petrify Antonin Dolohov who was pursuing him and his friends, and used on Harry by Draco Malfoy in the Hogwarts Express in 1996.
138.content: Curse: Used to temporarily bind the victim's body in a position much like that of a soldier at attention; the victim will usually fall to the ground.

139.comment: Pronounced peer-TOH-tuhm loh-kuh-MOH-tor. Etymology: Pier means "friend" or "colleague", totum refers to "the whole" or "total", and locomotor means "the movement of". In the Battle of Hogwarts, Professor McGonagall used this spell to animate the suits of armour and statues within Hogwarts, to defend the castle. Also used by Albus Dumbledore to enchant the statues on the fountain in the entrance to the Ministry of Magic Department.

141.comment: Hermione Granger taught it to Harry Potter, who used it during the Triwizard Tournament, particularly to navigate the hedge maze during the Third Task.
141.content: Spell: Makes the caster's wand point due north.

142.comment: Pronounced POR-tus. Etymology: Latin porta, meaning "gate", or portare, meaning "to carry" (as in to carry the caster or target to another location). There is a Latin word portus, meaning "harbour", but it is inappropriate in this context. Portkeys were first seen in 1994 as a means for Harry, Hermione, and the Weasleys to go to the Quidditch World Cup. However, the spell used in its creation was not seen until 1995. Used by Albus Dumbledore in 1996.
142.content: Charm: Turns an object into a portkey.

143.comment: Pronounced pri-OR in-can-TAH-toh. Etymology: Latin prior, "previous", and incantare, "to speak a spell" (past participle incantatum). Can manifest in the form of the Reverse Spell effect, or Priori Incantatem, when wands with the same core attempt to do battle. Used by Amos Diggory in 1994 to discover the last spell cast by Harry's wand after it was found in the hands of Winky, a house-elf.
143.content: Charm: Forces a wand to show an "echo" of the last spell it performed.

144.content: Jinx, Transfiguration: Transforms things into chickens.

145.comment: Pronounced pro-TAY-goh. Etymology: Latin protego, "I cover" or "I protect". The original description of this spell states that it rebounds minor jinxes to the caster. However, it is shown that it can also be used to reflect or lessen the effects of more powerful spells, depending on the skill of the caster. In 1998, it is also shown to be able to create a sort of force-field across an area, and is used frequently to prevent two participants in an argument from reaching each other. First seen in 1995, in which Harry is taught this spell by Hermione in preparation for the third task in the Triwizard Tournament. Albus Dumbledore uses a similar spell which reverses the construction of glass back into sand when Voldemort sent shards of glass to try to stab Dumbledore. Fred and George Weasley enchanted hats they dubbed "shield hats" with this spell in 1997.
145.content: Charm: Invisible shield that reflects spells and blocks physical entities.

146.content: Dark Arts: Conjures a protective ring of black fire around the caster that only affects their enemies.

147.comment: Pronounced pro-TAY-goh horr-uh-BIHL-ihs. Etymology: Latin Protego, "I protect", and Horribilis, "horrible , frightful, dreadful". Cast by Professor Flitwick in an attempt to strengthen the castle's defences in the Battle of Hogwarts.
147.content: Charm: A powerful shield charm against dark magic.

148.comment: Pronounced pro-TAY-goh MAX-ee-Ma. Etymology: Latin Protego, "I protect" Cast by Professor Flitwick, Professor McGonagall, Professor Slughorn and Mrs Weasley in an attempt to strengthen the castle's defences in the Battle of Hogwarts.
148.content: Charm: A powerful shield charm against dark magic. A stronger and bigger version of Protego, especially when combined with other wizards casting it at the same time. Was so powerful that it could also disintegrate people that came too close and tried to enter it.

149.comment: Pronounced pro-TAY-goh toh-TAH-lum. Etymology: Latin protego meaning "to protect" and Latin totus meaning "as a whole". In 1997, this was one of the spells used by Hermione Granger and Harry Potter to protect their camp site from unwanted visitors.
149.content: Charm: Protects an area for an extended period of time.

150.comment: Pronounced KWIY-uh-tus. Etymology: Latin quietus, "calm" or "quiet". Used in 1994 by Ludo Bagman.
150.content: Charm: Makes a target sound quieter. It is the counter-charm to the Amplifying Charm.

151.content: Dark charm: Shrinks the head of the target. It is the counter-spell to Engorgio Skullus.

152.comment: Pronounced re-DOO-see-oh. Etymology: English reduce, "to shrink". (Latin has a verb reducere, present tense reduco. This is the source of the English "reduce", but has a different meaning.) Also in Italian Riduco first person present tense of Ridurre, same root of Latin Reducere. Whether Reducio could also be used by itself rather than countering Engorgio is unknown. If it could, it would shrink normal sized items into miniature versions of themselves. References in 1992 by Arthur Weasley to "shrinking door keys" make this seem likely. In 1997, Harry Potter, after checking his Blackthorn wand on the Bluebell Flames with Engorgio, casts this spell to shorten the formerly enlarged flames.
152.content: Charm: Makes an object shrink in size. Its counter-charm is the Engorgement Charm.

153.comment: Pronounced re-DUK-toh. Etymology: English reduce, "to bring down;destroy". In 1995, Harry used it on one of the hedges of the Triwizard maze and ends up burning a small hole in it; in 1995, Gryffindors in Harry Potter's year referenced Parvati Patil as being able to reduce a table full of Dark Detectors to ashes, and Harry and his friends later used the spell in the Department of Mysteries against the Death Eaters, shattering many Prophecy Orbs in the process; in 1997, a member of the Order of the Phoenix attempted to use this spell to break down a door which Death Eaters had blocked when the Death Eaters had cornered Dumbledore in the Lightning Struck Tower.
153.content: Curse: Breaks objects. In stronger usages, disintegrates them.

154.content: Healing Spell: Reverts minor magically-induced ailments, such as paralysis and poisoning.

155.comment: Pronounced ree-VUHR-tay. Etymology: Reverte is derived from Latin for "you shall return", being a second-person imperative form (singular, present, active) of the verb reverto ("I return, or turn back"). In 1927, Leta Lestrange used this spell on the record towers in the French Ministry of Magic Records Room at the French Ministry of Magic Headquarters, in an attempt to flee from pursuing Matagots. This sent all the record towers - previously summoned by Lestrange - flying backwards and spinning back into their original positions in the ground.
155.content: Charm: Returns objects to their original positions or states.

156.comment: Pronounced ruh-LASH-ee-oh. Etymology: Probably from the French verb relcher ="to release, to set free", or Italian rilascio (pronounced the same way as the spell)= "I release". Used by Harry Potter against Grindylows in the second task of the Triwizard Tournament. Also used in 1997 and 1998, when Hermione used this spell to free Mary Cattermole from the chained chair and to free the Ukrainian Ironbelly on which they were to get out from Gringotts.
156.content: Jinx: Forces the target to release its grip on whatever it is holding.

157.comment: Pronounced RENN-a-vate. Etymology: Rennervate means "to energise. In 1994, Amos Diggory used it to wake up Winky and Albus Dumbledore used it to wake up Viktor Krum. Harry Potter later used it to try and reawaken a cursed Dumbledore in the seaside cave.
157.content: Charm: Awakens an unconscious victim. It is consequently the counter-charm to the Stunning Spell.

158.comment: Pronounced reh-PAR-i-farj. Found in A Beginner's Guide to Transfiguration.
158.content: Untransfiguration: Used to reverse incomplete transformations.

159.comment: Pronounced reh-PAH-roh. Etymology: Latin reparo meaning "to renew" or "repair". Reparo has been seen to repair non-magical items, however it seems to have an inability at repairing magical items or items that have magic placed upon them. An example is Harry's Nimbus 2000 shown in 1993 which he is told is irreparable after it is destroyed by the Whomping Willow. Wands are also irreparable, as shown in 1992 when Ron's wand snapped after he and Harry crashed onto the Hogwarts grounds. Despite his use of Spellotape, Ron's wand malfunctioned throughout the year. Another example is in 1997 when Hermione tried to fix Harry's broken wand, which was snapped by her errant Blasting Curse. However, Harry repaired his wand with the Elder Wand. Since the Elder Wand is the most powerful wand in creation, it makes sense that it would produce the most powerful Mending Charm. Used by Albus Dumbledore and Horace Slughorn to repair damage the latter had done to a Muggle home in Budleigh Babberton where he had been hiding. It was also used by Harry Potter to repair his wand with the Elder Wand

160.comment: Pronounced ruh-PEL-oh MUH-guhl-tuhm. It was used to keep Muggles away from the Quidditch World Cup. Hogwarts was also said to be guarded by the Muggle-Repelling Charm. It was also used by Harry and Hermione on numerous occasions, among many other spells, to protect and hide their camp site in 1997.
160.content: Charm: Keeps Muggles away from wizarding places by causing them to remember important meetings they missed and to cause the Muggles in question to forget what they were doing.

161.comment: Pronounced re-PEH-lloh ee-nee-MEE-cum. Etymology: Latin "Repello", meaning "Push Back" and "inimicum", the accusative singular form of "inimcus" meaning "foe" or "enemy". This spell was used by professors Filius Flitwick and Horace Slughorn along with Order of the Phoenix member Molly Weasley to protect Hogwarts Castle in 1998.
161.content: Charm: Disintegrates the persons entering this charm.

162.content: Charm: Reveals secrets about a person or object.

163.comment: Pronounced ric-tuhs-SEM-pra. Etymology: Possibly the sum of two words; The Latin rictus, meaning "The expanse of an open mouth", and semper, meaning "Always". Rictus is generally used as an expression of terror, however, "always an open mouth" would, in most cases, correspond to the act of laughing uncontrollably. By Harry Potter on Draco Malfoy in 1992, when they fought in the Duelling Club.
163.content: Charm: Tickles the target until they become weak with laughter.

164.comment: Pronounced rih-dih-KUL-lus. Etymology: Latin word ridiculus, "laughable" (but perhaps "absurd" or "silly" in this context). The effect of the spell seems to rely primarily on the state of mind of the caster. It doesn't actually change the shape of a boggart into something humorous, but rather whatever the caster is concentrating on at the moment of the casting, as when Neville was thinking of his grandmother's dress. Presumably, Mrs Weasley couldn't take her mind off of her fears for her family, so the Boggart was changed into other members of the family rather than something humorous. Taught by Remus Lupin during third year Defence Against the Dark Arts, where his students had the opportunity to practise the spell on an actual Boggart.
164.content: Charm: A spell used when fighting a Boggart, "Riddikulus" forces the Boggart to take the appearance of an object the caster is focusing on. Best results can be achieved if the caster is focusing on something humorous, with the desire that laughter will weaken the Boggart.

165.comment: Pronounced SAL-vee-oh HECKS-ee-ah. Etymology: Possibly derived from the Latin "salveo," meaning "to be in good health," and used as a form of greeting and farewell, and a pseudo-Latin derivative of the English word "hex"hence, "Farewell, hexes!" Possibly the Hex Deflection spells the fake Moody mentioned in 1994. Harry and Hermione cast this spell to strengthen their camp-site's defences against intruders in 1997.

166.comment: Pronounced SKUR-ji-fy. Etymology: Perhaps related to English scour, "clean". -ify is a common English suffix meaning "to make ...". Therefore scourgify could mean "to make clean". First used by Nymphadora Tonks to clean Hedwig's cage in 1995. Later, Ginny Weasley performed the spell to clean up the Stinksap on the Hogwarts Express, also used by James Potter on Severus Snape after he shouted various curses and obscenities at him.

167.comment: Pronounced sec-tum-SEMP-rah. Etymology: Latin sectum, "cut", and semper, "always". The spell can apparently be used against any object, but was not effective when used against Inferi because they could not feel pain or bleed. The movement of the wand seems to affect how someone is cut, suggested by the erratic patterns of slashes left on Draco Malfoy's face and chest, produced by Harry Potter's wild wand-swings while using the spell against Draco. Wounds caused by this spell can be healed as proved by Severus Snape who after Harry hit Draco Malfoy with this spell he healed Draco's wounds and told him to go and get treated with dittany at once so that he would even avoid any sign of any wound. However it seems that it depends on the caster's magical abilities because Molly Weasley could not heal and restore George Weasley's ear that was cursed off by this spell. Used by Harry in 1997 against Draco Malfoy, and then later against both the Inferi in Lord Voldemort's Horcrux cave, and Snape used it against George Weasley (was unintentional; aimed for a Death Eater that tried to curse Lupin) in the Order's flight from Privet Drive. Harry learned it in Snape's old Potions textbook. In 1998, the spell is said to be Severus Snape's "signature" spell.
167.content: Curse: Lacerates the target, as if they have been "slashed by a sword." Subsequently, the target can easily bleed to death from the wounds. This curse was invented by Severus Snape, to be used against his personal enemies.

168.comment: Pronounced ser-pen-SOR-shah, SER-pehn-SOR-tee-ah. Etymology: Latin serpens meaning "a snake" and Latin ortis meaning "source". Used by Draco Malfoy while duelling Harry Potter in 1992.
168.content: Conjuration: Conjures a serpent from the caster's wand.

169.comment: Pronounced sih-LEN-see-oh. Etymology: Probably Latin silentium, "silence". Also, silencio and silncio (which is closer to the English pronunciation) mean "silence" in Spanish and Portuguese, respectively. First used by Hermione in 1996 to silence a frog and a raven in Charms class, then later used to silence a Death Eater that was trying to tell his comrades where they were.

170.comment: Pronounced SKURJ. Taught in second year Charms class.
170.content: Charm: Cleans up ectoplasm and frightens ghosts and other spirits.

171.comment: In 1992, Ronald Weasley attempted to curse Draco Malfoy with this spell after the latter insulted Hermione Granger, but was unsuccessful as his wand at the time was broken, and thus his curse backfired on himself.
171.content: Curse: Forces the victim to burp up slimy slugs.

172.comment: Pronounced soh-NOHR-uhs. Etymology: Latin sonorus, "loud; noisy". By Ludo Bagman in 1994 at the beginning of the Quidditch World Cup and by Albus Dumbledore several times in the Triwizard Championship. Used by Lord Voldemort several times during the Battle of Hogwarts in 1998.
172.content: Charm: Makes the target sound louder. The counter-charm is the Quietening Charm, Quietus.

173.comment: Pronounced spe-see-AL-is reh-VEL-ee-oh. Etymology: Latin specialis, "particular;individual" and revelare (present tense revelo), "unveil". In 1994, Severus Snape cast a similar spell, but with different words ("Reveal your secrets!"), on the Marauder's Map, though he may have just been saying those words as he cast the spell non-verbally. Used by Hermione Granger to find out more of Harry's Advanced Potion-Making book in 1996. Used by Ernie Macmillan to find out ingredients of a potion.
173.content: Charm: Reveals spells cast on objects or potions.

174.comment: Pronounced SPUN-ji-fye. This charm is found in The Standard Book of Spells, Grade 1.
174.content: Charm: Softens objects, making them rubbery and bouncy.

175.comment: Pronounced STEH-lee-us, or perhaps STEH-nee-us. Etymology: Sternius derives from the Latin sternuo, meaning I sneeze.
175.content: Dark charm: A spell that causes the victim to sneeze for a short period of time. This spell is used in duelling to distract the opponent.

176.comment: Pronounced STOO-puh-fye. Etymology: English stupefy, which means 'to put into a stupor', a temporary vegetative state. The physical manifestation of the spell is a beam of red light emanating from the caster's wand. The spell wears off after a short time, and can be countered by Rennervate. Nearly useless on magic-resistant creatures such as dragons, trolls and giants unless more than one Stupefy spell is used at the same time. The force of the spell is additive or perhaps even exponential, and it can cause severe injury if many spells are used on a target that is not normally resistant to its effects. Hagrid, as a half-giant, was impervious to this spell - or at least, a lone one. Often; particularly by a number of wizards and witches (including Dolores Umbridge) against Minerva McGonagall in 1996. It's also taught by Harry in his D.A. meetings.
176.content: Charm: Stuns the target, rendering them unconscious.

177.comment: Pronounced SUR-jee-toh. Etymology: Surgito is a Latin word in the imperative form meaning "you/he/she shall arise, or get up", and is a conjugation of the verb surgo ("I arise"). The etymology is appropriate, considering that the effects of the spell on Jacob Kowalski can be likened to waking up from a confused, dreamlike state. In 1927, Newton Scamander used Surgito to lift an enchantment that was placed on Jacob Kowalski. As a result of the spell, Kowalski awoke from the dreamlike enchanted state, and regained an awareness of reality in the present.
177.content: Counter-charm: Counter-charm that can be used to remove enchantments.

178.comment: Pronounced ta-RON-ta-LEG-gra. Etymology: Italian tarantella, a kind of fast country dance once popular in parts of Italy, supposedly from the frantic motion caused by the bite of a tarantula; and allegro, a musical term meaning "quick". First used by Draco Malfoy on Harry Potter in the Duelling Club in 1992.
178.content: Charm: Makes a target's legs spasm wildly out of control, making it appear as though they are dancing.

179.content: Transfiguration, Jinx: Transfigures the target's head into a tentacle.

180.comment: Pronounced TUR-jee-oh. Etymology: Latin tergere, "wipe off; cleanse". Hermione Granger used the spell in 1996 to remove blood from Harry's face. It is later used to remove spilled ink from parchment. It was also used in 1997 to clean off a handkerchief by Ron and to dust off a picture of Gellert Grindelwald in Bathilda Bagshot's house by Harry Potter.
180.content: Charm: Siphons liquid and cleans objects.

181.content: Hex: Tickles and weakens the victim.

182.content: Charm: Causes the quality of food within a location to be improved.

183.comment: Pronounced VEN-tuss. Etymology: Ventus is a Latin word, meaning "wind". Used by Newton Scamander to send away Stebbins on a London street, much to the bemusement of passing Muggles.
183.content: Charm: Shoots a jet of strong spiralling wind from the tip of the wand.

184.comment: In Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (video game)
184.content: Jinx: A stronger version of the Windy Spell

185.comment: Pronounced vair-uh-VAIR-toh. Etymology: From Latin vera meaning "right" or "proper", and verto, meaning I turn. Taught by Minerva McGonagall in her Transfiguration class. Also used by Ronald Weasley unsuccessfully in one of his second year classes thanks to his damaged wand.
185.content: Transfiguration: Turn animals to water goblets.

186.content: Charm: A spell used to shoot green sparks from the end of the wand.

187.comment: Pronounced vur-duh-MILL-ee-us. This spell is almost certainly the incantation for Green Sparks. Taught in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher's office class.
187.content: Charm: Produces a jet of green sparks that can be used in duelling, or to reveal things hidden by dark magic.

188.comment: Pronounced VERD-dee-MILL-lee-us. Learned in first year Defence Against the Dark Arts.
188.content: Charm: A more powerful version of Verdimillious.

189.comment: Pronounced vur-MICK-yoo-luhs. This spell may have some connection with Squiggle Quill.
189.content: Transfiguration, Jinx: Transforms things into worms.

190.content: Charm: Jet of red sparks that can be used to signal an emergency or as a minor duelling spell.

191.comment: Pronounced vee-PAIR-uh eh-vuh-NES-kuh. Etymology: Vipera is a genus of venomous vipers, a type of snake. Evanesca likely shares its origin with Evanesco, which means "disappear" in Latin. Severus Snape cast this spell in 1992 at the Duelling Club to vanish a snake that Draco Malfoy had conjured while duelling Harry Potter. Albus Dumbledore also used this spell to vanish Voldemort's snake during their Duel in the Ministry Atrium.
191.content: Vanishment: Vanishes snakes. Subsequently, it is the counter-spell for the Snake Summons Spell.

192.comment: Pronounced VUL-ner-ah sah-NEN-tour. Etymology: Vulnera Sanentur derives from the Latin vulnus, "wound," and sanare, "to heal"; it is translated "may the wounds be healed." Used by Severus Snape to heal the wounds of Draco Malfoy caused by the Sectumsempra curse cast by Harry Potter in 1997.
192.content: Healing Spell: Healing spell that slows blood flow, clears residue, and knits wounds. It is the counter-curse to Sectumsempra.

193.comment: Pronounced wah-deh-WAH-see. Etymology: "Waddiwasi" comes from two words. "Vadd" and "vas-y". "Vadd" is a Swedish word that can mean "wadding" and "vas-y" is French term that means "go ahead" or "Come on!" Together, they can roughly mean "The wad goes ahead." This spell may be related to the Oppugno Jinx. Cast by Remus Lupin in 1993, on Peeves the Poltergeist, sending a wad of chewing gum up his nose.
193.content: Charm: Used to shoot small, soft masses of whatever the caster so desires at the target

194.comment: Pronounced win-GAR-dee-um lev-ee-OH-sa. Etymology: "Wingardium" almost certainly contains English wing, meaning "fly", and Latin arduus, meaning "high". "Leviosa" probably originates from Latin levis, meaning "light". This spell is taught in early first-year charms classes; this came into good use later in that year, when Ron Weasley performed the spell to knock out a mountain troll; six years later, Harry uses the charm to levitate the side-car of his godfather's flying motorbike; Ron used it again this year to make a twig poke a tree.
194.content: Charm: Makes objects fly, or levitate.
